Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Surface and Electrochemical Processes in Co-Electrolysis of Carbon Dioxide and Water

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project targets co-electrolysis of carbon dioxide and water in high-temperature solid oxide electrolysis cells (SOECs) to make synthesis gas, which can be further reacted to produce fuels and chemicals. Although attractive from a sustainability standpoint, there are many technological hurdles to overcome before co-electrolysis can become commercially feasible. The study will investigate the surface reactions at the electrode to determine their mechanisms, kinetics, and sensitivity to different materials. The resulting scientific insight should lead to the design of improved co-electrolyzers. The PI will couple the work with educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, as well as learning experiences and research exposure for high-school and community college students.

Co-electrolysis of carbon dioxide and water to produce synthesis gas is a daunting technological challenge, but one with huge benefits to energy and overall sustainability if it can be achieved. One key to achieving success is to build fundamental understanding of the surface reaction processes involved, and use the resulting insight to design better catalysts. The project will focus on mixed conducting ceria and perovskite SOEC cathodes with the goal of constructing kinetic models of surface reactions. Specifically, the project will combine analysis of gas phase reaction products and electrochemical measurements to elucidate catalytic mechanisms and reaction pathways, including rate limiting steps. The resulting insight will be used to understand dependence of electrolysis reactions on properties of the cathode, with potential for extending the general approach to predict new cathode materials and designs.


The fundamental understanding that will come from the proposed work will potentially impact a broad range of electrocatalytic applications with related benefits to energy and sustainability. On the education side, the PI (Stuve) teaches two energy related classes each year that are innovative in nature and highly suscribed. The project also supports a novel outreach program - the Energy eXperience Project (EXP) - which gives high school and community college students an opportunity to experience hands on energy-related work at the University of Washington through an annual symposium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Emission of greenhouse gases, particularly CO2, is widely considered to be a major cause of climate change.  This has led to growing interest in carbon capture and utilization (CCU) processes that use electrical energy from renewable sources to recover CO2 from the environment.  One possible route to CO2 capture is co-electrolysis of CO2 and H2O to make synthesis gas (CO and H2), which can be used in fuel cells or chemically processed to liquid fuels, as shown in Fig. 1.  Many technological hurdles exist ? such as reaction mechanisms, kinetics, and effect of different electrode catalysts ? before co-electrolysis can be commercially feasible.

The goal of this project is to describe the electrochemical and catalytic properties of SOEC electrocatalysts.  Our approach involves a unique combination of techniques that enable chemical reaction and electrochemical processes to be studied together.  Both techniques are based on analysis of characteristic frequencies of electrochemical and chemical reactions.  In electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), an oscillating voltage at a certain frequency, when applied to an electrochemical cell, produces an oscillating current in the form of oxygen ions at the same frequency, as shown in Fig. 2.  The oscillating current produces oscillating reaction rates that can be measured with a mass spectrometer.  This defines the new technique of Frequency Resolved Mass Spectrometry (FRMS), which was developed in this research. 

The FRMS technique processes mass spectrometer data by a Fourier transform analysis to determine the signal harmonics and thereby identify the reactions.  With FRMS, both reactions and reacting species can be identified and monitored as a function of frequency and other reaction conditions such as temperature and pressure.

The combined EIS and FRMS methods were applied to the study of co-electrolysis of H2O and CO2 (reactions 1 and 2).  The mechanism of these co-reacting species is complicated by the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS, reaction 3), in which CO2 and H2 react to produce CO and H2O.  While water electrolysis is known as a relatively fast reaction, CO2 electrolysis is thought to be slow in comparison, so it is possible for the RWGS reaction to convert CO2 to CO instead.  The FRMS technique enables the question of whether CO2 occurs by electrolysis or by RWGS to be answered.

The function of FRMS can be explained by an analogy to music.  Just as a musical instrument can produce many notes and a musical note can be produced by many instruments, a chemical reaction can consume or produce many different species and each species can be involved in many reactions.  The FRMS technique distinguishes species from reactions by tuning in to the mass of each species (2 for H2, 44 for CO2) and monitoring each signal as a function of frequency to determine the harmonics that identify the reactions.

Conversion of CO2 and H2O into synthesis gas (CO and H2) was studied on a gadolinium-doped ceria (GDC) electrocatalyst in a solid oxide electrolyte cell at 800 ?C.  The electrolyte was yttrium-stabilized zirconia (YSZ), and the anode was a platinum electrocatalyst.  Electrochemical impedance measurements showed that the main reactions had unique responses in the frequency range of 6 to 80 mHz.  (1 mHz is one oscillation per 1000 seconds.)  The mass spectrometer was tuned to masses 2 (H2) and 44 (CO2) to measure their consumption or production during the oscillations.  The result was that H2 production responded to all frequencies within the 6 to 80 mHz range, whereas CO2 consumption responded only at the lower frequencies of 6 and 10 mHz.  This means that H2 production by H2O electrolysis is fast, while CO2 consumption is slow.  By measuring the the time delay between H2 production and CO2 consumption, the FRMS technique showed that CO2 consumption occurs by RWGS.  CO2 electrolysis does not occur at an appreciable rate in these measurements.

This research has produced two main findings.  First, and specific to the reaction of study, the RWGS reaction is the dominant reaction for carbon capture on a GDC electrocatalyst at 800 ?C.  This has important implications in the design of new electrocatalysts that will make electrochemical carbon capture commercially feasible.

Second, and more broadly important, the FRMS technique has been shown to provide direct information on reaction mechanism that would have taken much longer to determine by traditional methods.  The FRMS technique is not limited to electrochemical reactions, nor is it limited to specific chemical species.  It can be used to study catalytic and gas phase reactions involving any species.  The FRMS technique is still in its infancy, however.  Further development is required to improve its frequency range, especially to higher frequencies, and detection limits.  With its ability to identify reaction mechanisms quickly, the FRMS technique has the potential to become a transformational tool for kinetics research.

    Eric Stuve

    Eric M Stuve
    Frequency Resolved Mass Spectrometry
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Emission of greenhouse gases, particularly CO2, is widely considered to be a major cause of climate change. This has led to growing interest in carbon capture and utilization (CCU) processes that use electrical energy from renewable sources to recover CO2 from the environment. One possible route to CO2 capture is co-electrolysis of CO2 and H2O to make synthesis gas (CO and H2), which can be used in fuel cells or chemically processed to liquid fuels, as shown in Fig. 1. Many technological hurdles exist ? such as reaction mechanisms, kinetics, and effect of different electrode catalysts ? before co-electrolysis can be commercially feasible. The goal of this project is to describe the electrochemical and catalytic properties of SOEC electrocatalysts. Our approach involves a unique combination of techniques that enable chemical reaction and electrochemical processes to be studied together. Both techniques are based on analysis of characteristic frequencies of electrochemical and chemical reactions. In electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), an oscillating voltage at a certain frequency, when applied to an electrochemical cell, produces an oscillating current in the form of oxygen ions at the same frequency, as shown in Fig. 2. The oscillating current produces oscillating reaction rates that can be measured with a mass spectrometer. This defines the new technique of Frequency Resolved Mass Spectrometry (FRMS), which was developed in this research. The FRMS technique processes mass spectrometer data by a Fourier transform analysis to determine the signal harmonics and thereby identify the reactions. With FRMS, both reactions and reacting species can be identified and monitored as a function of frequency and other reaction conditions such as temperature and pressure. The combined EIS and FRMS methods were applied to the study of co-electrolysis of H2O and CO2 (reactions 1 and 2). The mechanism of these co-reacting species is complicated by the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS, reaction 3), in which CO2 and H2 react to produce CO and H2O. While water electrolysis is known as a relatively fast reaction, CO2 electrolysis is thought to be slow in comparison, so it is possible for the RWGS reaction to convert CO2 to CO instead. The FRMS technique enables the question of whether CO2 occurs by electrolysis or by RWGS to be answered. The function of FRMS can be explained by an analogy to music. Just as a musical instrument can produce many notes and a musical note can be produced by many instruments, a chemical reaction can consume or produce many different species and each species can be involved in many reactions. The FRMS technique distinguishes species from reactions by tuning in to the mass of each species (2 for H2, 44 for CO2) and monitoring each signal as a function of frequency to determine the harmonics that identify the reactions. Conversion of CO2 and H2O into synthesis gas (CO and H2) was studied on a gadolinium-doped ceria (GDC) electrocatalyst in a solid oxide electrolyte cell at 800 ?C. The electrolyte was yttrium-stabilized zirconia (YSZ), and the anode was a platinum electrocatalyst. Electrochemical impedance measurements showed that the main reactions had unique responses in the frequency range of 6 to 80 mHz. (1 mHz is one oscillation per 1000 seconds.) The mass spectrometer was tuned to masses 2 (H2) and 44 (CO2) to measure their consumption or production during the oscillations. The result was that H2 production responded to all frequencies within the 6 to 80 mHz range, whereas CO2 consumption responded only at the lower frequencies of 6 and 10 mHz. This means that H2 production by H2O electrolysis is fast, while CO2 consumption is slow. By measuring the the time delay between H2 production and CO2 consumption, the FRMS technique showed that CO2 consumption occurs by RWGS. CO2 electrolysis does not occur at an appreciable rate in these measurements. This research has produced two main findings. First, and specific to the reaction of study, the RWGS reaction is the dominant reaction for carbon capture on a GDC electrocatalyst at 800 ?C. This has important implications in the design of new electrocatalysts that will make electrochemical carbon capture commercially feasible. Second, and more broadly important, the FRMS technique has been shown to provide direct information on reaction mechanism that would have taken much longer to determine by traditional methods. The FRMS technique is not limited to electrochemical reactions, nor is it limited to specific chemical species. It can be used to study catalytic and gas phase reactions involving any species. The FRMS technique is still in its infancy, however. Further development is required to improve its frequency range, especially to higher frequencies, and detection limits. With its ability to identify reaction mechanisms quickly, the FRMS technique has the potential to become a transformational tool for kinetics research.
